chapter.title: Bibliography
chapter.para: Most of the information in this book has been extracted from the kernel documentation and source code. This is the best place for information on how to build and install the kernel, and is usually kept up to date when things in the build procedure change.

sect1.title: Books
sect1.para: There are a number of very good Linux kernel programming books availble, but only a few that deal with building and installing the kernel. Here is a list of books that the author has found useful when dealing with the Linux kernel.

varlistentry.term: Ellen Siever, Aaron Weber, Stephen Figgins, Robert Love, Arnold Robbins. Linux in a Nutshell, Fifth Edition. O'Reilly & Associates, 2005

listitem.para: This book can be has the most complete and authoritative command reference for Linux. It covers almost every different command that you will ever need to use.

varlistentry.term: Yaghmour, Karim. Building Embedded Systems. O'Reilly & Associates, 2003.

listitem.para: This book, although mainly oriented toward the embedded Linux developer, has a great section on how to build up a cross-compiler toolchain and kernel. It is highly recommended for that, as well as other portions of this book that are very relevant for people wishing to learn more about how to customise a Linux kernel and the rest of the system.

sect2.title: Linux Kernel Books
sect2.para: Most of these books are oriented toward the programmer who is interested in learning how to program within the kernel. They are much more technically oriented than this book, but are a great place to start if you wish to learn more about the code that controls the kernel.

varlistentry.term: Jonathan Corbet, Alessandro Rubini, and Greg Kroah-Hartman. Linux Device Drivers, Third Edition. O'Reilly & Associates, 2005.

listitem.para: This book covers thow the different kernel device driver subsystems work, and provides lots of examples of working drivers. It is recommended for anyone wanting to work with Linux kernel drivers. It is also available online for free at http://lwn.net/Kernel/LDD3/.

varlistentry.term: Love, Robert.Linux Kernel Development, Second Edition. Novell Press Publishing, 2005.

listitem.para: Robert Love's book covers almost all areas of the Linux kernel, showing how everything works together. It is a great place to start learning about the different portions of the kernel internals.

varlistentry.term: Bovet, Daniel P. and Cesate, Marco. Understanding the Linux Kernel, Third Edition. O'Reilly & Associates, 2005.

listitem.para: This book goes into the design and implementation of the core Linux kernel. It is a great reference for understanding the algorithms used within the different portions of the kernel. It is highly recommended for anyone wanting to understand the details of how the kernel works.

sect1.title: Tool locations
sect1.para: A lot of different tools were mentioned in this book. Here are links to where the source code for these tools can be found on the internet.

listitem.para: http://www.kernel.org and ftp://ftp.kernel.org contain all of the different versions of the Linux kernel source code. http://www.kernel.org/git/ contains a listing of all git trees in use by the different kernel developers.
http://gcc.gnu.org/ is the main site for everything related to the Gnu C Compiler.
http://www.gnu.org/software/binutils/ is the main site for all information about binutils.
http://www.gnu.org/software/make/ is the main site for all information about make.
http://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/utils/util-linux/ is the directory for where all versions of util-linux can be downloaded.
http://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/utils/kernel/module-init-tools/ is the directory for where all versions of module-init-tools can be downloaded.
http://e2fsprogs.sourceforge.net/ is the main project page for the e2fsprogs package.
http://jfs.sourceforge.net/ is the main project page for the jfsutils package.
http://www.namesys.com/download.html is the main project page for the reiserfsprogs package.
http://oss.sgi.com/projects/xfs/ is the main project page for the xfsprogs package.
http://sourceforge.net/projects/linuxquota/ is the main project page for the quota-tools package.
http://nfs.sf.net/ is the main project page for the nfs-utils package.
http://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/utils/kernel/hotplug/udev.html is the directory for where all versions of udev can be downloaded.
http://procps.sourceforge.net/ is the main project page for the procfs package.
http://cyberelk.net/tim/patchutils is the location for all of the patchutils releases.
http://git.or.cz/ is the main site for the git project.
http://www.selenic.com/ketchup/ is the main project page for the ketchup program.
http://savannah.nongnu.org/projects/quilt is the main project page for the quilt program.
